TALK.START.PARA: —It is my privilege to propose to the House for its Speaker in the Thirty-third Parliament the honourable member for Scullin, Dr Harry Jenkins. I therefore move:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Clerk-Is there any further proposal? If there is no further proposal, the time for proposals has expired. I declare that the honourable member for Scullin (Dr Jenkins) has been elected as Speaker.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to express my grateful thanks for the high honour the House has been pleased to confer upon me.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Speaker having seated himself in the chair-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to congratulate you on your nomination from the majority party for the office of Speaker. Likewise, I was very pleased that there was no contesting nomination and we were spared the scarring of past parliaments when there was acrimonious debate on the matter. You, Mr Speaker, are a man of great integrity and your friendship I have enjoyed for many years, especially during my own term in the office of Speaker. You have great experience in the chair and your skill in the conduct of the House has earned respect from all sides.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from the duties seen in the House, a Speaker must give leadership in the interests of all members. He must speak for all members. He must put the protection of members and the discharge of their duties above all party considerations. Each member of this House has a duty to speak the truth and to demand the truth, and the Speaker is guardian of the right of each member to do so. The Speaker must be above party politics in this House.

Significant advances in the role of parliament in the national government in the last few years have brought opportunity for members to contribute better their abilities and their energies. Of all reforms achieved the most significant is that this Parliament has gained control over its own budget, with the passage last year of the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill. If Parliament is to discharge its constitutional role it must be served by highly competent staff. Parliamentary staff are now independent of the Public Service, with the Presiding Officers assuming complete autonomy in respect of parliamentary staffing arrangements. Functions previously carried out by the Executive concerning members of the Parliament have been transferred to the control of the Parliament and further functions are being progressively transferred. However, many reforms remain to be achieved. I was elected last month by the electorate of Bruce hoping-indeed, expecting-that I would be Speaker and could pursue these reforms. That is not to be and it will now be for you, Mr Speaker, to carry the reforming thrust. I know that you fully understand the need and I am confident that you will do so.

I have constantly argued both here and in the public forum for the adoption by this House of the Westminster convention in relation to the Speaker. Under that convention, a Speaker upon being elected to that high office resigns from his political party, does not engage in partisan controversy inside or outside the chamber, is re-elected unopposed as Speaker, is not opposed at general elections by the major parties, casts his vote on a casting basis so as to avoid any judgment on the merits of a question and resigns from the House upon resigning from the Speakership. Under that convention the Speaker is not only impartial but also is seen to be impartial. I believe it to be an essential ingredient for the best parliamentary democracy. Here the convention has not yet been adopted. Nevertheless, general knowledge and consideration of the convention have expanded and I believe the status of the Speaker has thereby been enhanced, together with an increase in the public perception of the status of parliament.

That the Westminster convention will eventually be adopted in this House is inevitable if the standing of the Parliament is to be further raised. During my term of office I endeavoured to apply such of the features of the convention as were consistent with reality. I rarely attended party meetings and confined my attendance to occasions when major issues of principle were to be discussed. I took no part in the development of day to day policies or in the examination of legislation. I knew nothing of the political tactics to be adopted in the House. I endeavoured always to act independently and fairly and I will do nothing which may subtract from the status of the Chair.

I believe it is essential that the incoming Speaker should not be handicapped in carrying out his onerous tasks. There should be no focal point in the House which may be seen as a potential challenge to the Speaker and certainly there must not be any capacity to politicise his conduct or his rulings. The presence in this chamber of a former Speaker would increase enormously the load that the new Speaker would have to bear. I do not want to see that happen and I will not see it happen. My presence can only subtract from your role, Mr Speaker. Inevitably, if I were to stay I would be called upon for advice in any questioning of your rulings. This could only undermine the Chair and must not be allowed to happen.

I am very conscious that, under the Westminster convention, when the Speaker leaves the chair he leaves the House. I think this is right. This Westminster practice has been firmly in place all this century and considerations of which I have spoken have led to its acceptance. I have weighed this principle against other considerations, both political and personal. I have concluded that the Westminster practice is correct and, pursuant to it, I intend to leave the Parliament and will resign forthwith. I have given 27 years of service in various capacities in this House. The first eight years were spent alongside my old and honourable friend Jim Killen. In our early days we were both called ' oncers'. Now we are the joint fathers of the House. As from the next sitting father of the House will be his undisputed and honourable role.

This occasion is traumatic to me and fills me with great sadness. I look at the magnificent chair that I had the honour to occupy for seven years. The chair is itself a replica of that which stood in the House of Commons at Westminster. It was presented to the Australian House of Representatives by the Empire Parliamentary Association to mark the opening of this House in Canberra on 9 May 1927. The arms and the canopy are carved in oak from the timbers of Westminster Hall, which date from 1399, and the hinged arm rests are taken from the oak of the Victory, Nelson's flagship at Trafalgar in 1805. A replica of that chair, a gift from this Parliament, has now been installed in Westminster to replace the original, which was destroyed in the bombing of London.

To all new members, I wish you success. I trust that you will acquire a deep commitment to the House and that you will be true parliamentarians. Mr Speaker, as the new occupant of the chair, you have a tremendous responsibility and duties to perform. I know that you will do the job well, and I wish you well.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure, Mr Speaker, that I add to the congratulations of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). I had intended to say a few words about your excellent parliamentary record, but that matter has already been covered. It has been a privilege for me to nominate you for two other reasons. SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, as one of the few ethnic Australians in the House of Representatives, I have often marvelled at your capacity to work with migrant Australians. Over a third of your constituents are overseas born, and you have an excellent rapport with them. I believe that your commitment to the equality of all Australians, men and women, whether born here or migrants to this country, will help to establish a valuable foundation on which this Parliament will be built-that is, equality and fairness.

It is because of your commitment to these values, Mr Speaker, and your accumulation of parliamentary experience that you have become greatly respected on both sides of the House for your impartiality, consistency and sense of national duty. Indeed, these qualities will be extremely important in ensuring that this Parliament performs its duty to the nation in a constructive and positive way, for I am sure that most honourable members will agree that the challenges we face in the Thirty-third Parliament are the greatest that any parliament has faced since the war, especially in view of the deepening economic crisis. To overcome these problems we shall need to ensure that all members of parliament from both sides make the maximum contribution. I am sure that you will be a sympathetic guide to ensure that these important goals are achieved.

—I shall go to heaven, where you are unlikely to be in attendance. I trespass on the time of the House for but a few minutes. I congratulate you most warmly, Mr Speaker, on your election. It is a pleasure for you, I know, to occupy the position of Speaker in this Parliament. I know that that pleasure is shared by all of your friends and supporters. SPEECH.PARA: Sir, I would hope that no person, either in this House or outside it, would regard it as some suffusion of political activity that your election to the office of Speaker was not opposed. This world is not consumed entirely by cynicism. You are there because you command the respect of all those who have sat in parliament with you. I vividly recall, towards the close of the last Parliament, when you, as Mr Deputy Speaker, presided over the Parliament and there was not a quorum. It would have been at your disposal and within your proper power to have adjourned the House until the next day. You did not do so. You adjourned the House for five minutes to give the Whips the opportunity of ensuring that there was a proper attendance in the House. Sir, that was very proper and a very fine parliamentary gesture. As the former Leader of the House, I recall with immense gratitude that you took it.

Sir, you carry with you the good wishes of us all and our willingness to assist you in every possible respect. For my part, I have not the slightest doubt that you walk in the splendid tradition of Speaker Lenthall of centuries ago, who declared to this effect: 'I have neither eyes to see nor tongue to speak otherwise than as directed by this House'.

Finally may I say that it was a sad moment when I heard this morning the final decision of my right honourable and learned friend the member for Bruce (Sir Billy Snedden) to leave us. He has held, and held genuinely, to the view that the position of Speaker should be elevated from the dust of conflict. This has been the case in the United Kingdom. The present Speaker of the House of Commons , Speaker Thomas, has indicated that, when the Conservative Government goes to the election, he, Speaker Thomas, as one who formerly held an affinity with the British Labour Party, will step down. Before that, Speaker Selwyn Lloyd took that view. Now the right honourable member for Bruce has declared to the Parliament and to the country his position. To have sat with a person in this chamber for all that period and now to arrive at a stage when the parliamentary break is made is not an experience that one can pass through unmoved and with equanimity. I say to my right honourable friend that the years we have spent together in times of sadness, in times of tragedy, in times of cheerfulness and in times of tension have been a wonderful human experience to have shared. I am sure that I speak on behalf of all who have had the pleasure of knowing him when I say that he goes from this Parliament commanding our respect, our admiration and, beyond that, our good wishes for the years ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will delay the House for only a few moments. Mr Speaker, I wish to congratulate you on assuming the office of Speaker. You have the experience which is required to carry it out in a manner which is appropriate to this Parliament. You will, I am sure, do this Parliament and yourself proud. I do not accept that past Speakers of any party have shown a degree of bias different to that which could be expected in a House where the Speaker has been a member of the government parties. I regret that the right honourable member for Bruce (Sir Billy Snedden) finds it necessary to resign from this Parliament. That is his decision. It is a decision which, I think, every member of this House will respect. I do not believe it was appropriate for this Parliament to start with suggestions that Australian Labor Party Speakers are biased. Labor Speakers quite often face more difficult tasks than those of their conservative colleagues and are more rarely in office. The right honourable member for Richmond (Mr Anthony) and I had one disagreement during my period in the chair which resulted in his being suspended from the chamber. I assure him that that was not an act of bias; it was a proper and responsible act by the Chair. I congratulate you, Mr Speaker, on assuming the office of Speaker. I am certain that you will not be subjected to any criticism by this House.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to convey my thanks to the honourable members who have spoken and for the way in which they addressed their remarks. They commented that I have demonstrated an ability to be impartial in the chair in trying to promote that robust and worthwhile debate for which Parliament exists. By not opposing my candidature they have sought to place the responsibility on me of carrying out my duty in an impartial manner. But I remind them that by that very act they have placed the responsibility upon themselves to accept that there is a judgment of what is fair and reasonable in robust debate and that someone must make the decision as to when the limits which should restrict the privileges that members enjoy are reached. I hope they will accept that responsibility.

INTERJECT.PARA: Certainly, as Speaker, I have started in an unorthodox manner. It is traditional for the call to go to the Government side first and then to the Opposition. On this occasion I called the right honourable member for Bruce (Sir Billy Snedden). I think, as he spoke, it became obvious to the House why he had risen so quickly and why I had given him the call. There is no doubt that the right honorable member, as Speaker, has given considerable thought to reform in the Parliament and has stimulated discussion. I am sure he is disappointed at the slow progress that has been made. I wonder at times whether we are talking about parliamentary evolution rather than reform. I am sure that is what he has been talking about, too. I know that when my friend the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) was the Speaker he thought the committee system should be investigated. No doubt many of our committee reforms arose from Speaker Scholes. I regret that former Speaker Snedden will not be with us in this Parliament. I think he still has much to add in the development of parliamentary procedures. I assure him that his presence would not have embarrassed me.

This process of evolution is illustrated, I think, when one considers the remarks of my nominator and seconder. We face a changing Parliament. Today we have members who neither are Australian-born nor come from the British Isles, as was once traditional. They represent a great section of our community. There are cultural differences. Parliament must adjust to those different views. The honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) mentioned the small increase in the female membership of the Parliament. The increase has been a great breakthrough and this Parliament will see more female members. It has now been demonstrated that the electorate does not have an aversion, as myth would have us believe, to members of the female sex being elected to Parliament, where they have shown their worth.

In our evolution I think the televising of parliamentary proceedings will be inevitable in the short term. We must adjust and work out how that will be best applied in our new and permanent Parliament House. We have to look also at our other procedures, particularly Question Time. It is about time that questions were really information-seeking and were made short and sharp by members. Likewise, the answers by Ministers should not be totally irrelevant to the questions or be ministerial statements. Ministerial statements should be made at the proper time. I hope that supplementary questions may be possible and that the parties can agree on that. I hope that we can continue with committee experimentation. We saw a debate in this chamber last week between the leaders of Australia about the economy of Australia. If we look at our own record in parliament, where honourable members are restricted by the bounds of the Budget debate or a matter of public importance, I think we see that there is a lesson to be learnt about parliament's ability to look at committee reports and to have general debates. I do not think I need say much more than that.

I am most grateful for the support I have received from my own party and for the remarks from the Opposition parties. The honourable member for Moreton (Sir James Killen) did not complete the story about my inquiries of his health in the mornings. So often I would feel his pulse and I would say: 'Jim, do you mind if we pause for a few moments of silent prayer'.

I wish the right honourable member for Bruce well. I have enjoyed working with him as a Deputy Speaker. We had a close relationship. I think the Parliament will be poorer for his leaving. I trust that over the term of this Parliament honourable members will be satisfied with my firmness of ruling and my efforts to see that they all have the opportunity to have their say but, please, do not expect me to extend the limits beyond reasonable ones. I thank the House.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Speech read as follows-
Honourable Members of the Parliament of Australia here assembled:
At the elections for both Houses of Parliament on 5 March 1983, the people of Australia declared firmly for a change of government and for a change of national direction.
You have been called together to consider a wide-ranging program of legislation designed to give effect to the mandate of the people.
The new Government has assumed office at a time of Australia's gravest economic crisis since the Great Depression fifty years ago.

In the twelve months from March 1982, unemployment grew from 6.6 per cent to 10 .4 per cent of the workforce. Unemployment among fifteen to nineteen year olds in the workforce rose above 29 per cent. It is estimated some two million of our fellow Australians are now living in poverty.
Accordingly, my new advisers will give the highest priority to the task of restoring sustained growth to the Australian economy, now in deep recession.
The Government, however, is deeply committed to the need for social, economic, legal and Parliamentary reform.

The work of reform, to create a more equal and a more just society, must continue side by side with the urgent task of removing the acute injustice and deprivation caused by Australia's present massive unemployment.
The Economy

In fulfilment of an important undertaking given during the recent elections, my Government invited representatives of the governments, business and industrial unions of Australia to assemble in the national capital for a National Economic Summit Conference.

My advisers are confident that this historic Conference has achieved wider community understanding of the nature of the economic problems facing Australia and broad agreement upon a national effort to attack those problems.

The agreement reached at the Conference contains the basic framework and approach to enable Australia to begin to arrest the serious economic decline and place the economy on a path of sustained, non-inflationary growth. My advisers have assured the participants at the Summit and their representative organisations of the Government's support and assistance in building upon the foundations laid so successfully at the Conference. An essential ingredient to the success of the Conference was the dissemination of information to an extent not previously attempted in Australia. My advisers have undertaken that this process of information-sharing, which they believe essential to the making of sound economic decisions, will continue.
Certain matters arising from the Conference will require legislative action which you will be asked to consider during this Session.

The Government will establish an Economic Planning Advisory Council, representing governments, business, unions, farmers and community groups, to advise on economic developments and provide a forum for community consultation on national economic and social strategies.

The Government will establish a price surveillance mechanism to assess pricing decisions made by the strategic price setters, in both the private and public sectors. The Government will also review the structure and operation of the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority to ensure adequate supervision of petroleum prices.

My new Government has inherited a budgetary deficit problem of an unprecedented magnitude. A comprehensive review of budgetary commitments, both in terms of outlays and taxation expenditures, has been set in train.
Nevertheless, within the severe budgetary constraints it has inherited, the Government will give the highest priority to measures to create jobs and restore economic growth.
My Government will give high priority to combating tax avoidance and evasion. Legislation on this and other taxation matters will be introduced during the present Session.
Employment and Industrial Relations

A Community Works Program will be established. This Program, including Jobs on Local Roads, will be designed to provide jobs on projects of lasting benefit to the community which would not otherwise have been commenced.
A new Private Sector Assistance Program will be introduced to co-ordinate and enhance the value of existing programs. This program will give special emphasis to the needs of the young unemployed.
An Australian Labour Office will be established to develop a comprehensive work force strategy.
My advisers believe that better industrial relations are essential in the achievement of national economic recovery.

To this end the National Labour Consultative Council will be developed as the major forum for consultation on industrial relations matters and a tripartite review of the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act will be conducted.
Legislation will be introduced this Session to abolish the Industrial Relations Bureau and to facilitate trade union amalgamation.
Measures will be taken to improve the working environment by programs to enhance the standard of occupational health and safety and by encouraging the expansion of industrial democracy.
Secondary Industry

The development of a strong, competitive manufacturing industry will be of crucial importance to my Government's efforts towards national recovery and reconstruction. The Government will develop a program of industrial regeneration to revitalise existing industries and seek new opportunities for growth in areas of high technology. The Australian Industry Development Corporation will be given an enhanced status and provided with adequate funds to promote industrial reconstruction and develop new industries.
The Government intends to preserve a viable and efficient steel industry and is engaged in consultation with a view to formulating a long-term development plan.
The technological capability of Australian industry will be improved by incentive measures to stimulate research and development.

The role of the Industries Assistance Commission will be reviewed to ensure that its operations are directed towards the development and extension of industry. Temporary assistance and anti-dumping procedures are being reviewed as a matter of urgency.

It is my Government's policy not to reduce existing protection programs in current conditions of high unemployment. Legislation will be introduced to give effect to the accelerated depreciation allowance on plant and machinery, together with 2 1/2 per cent depreciation allowance on non-residential income- producing buildings.
Parliament will be asked to consider a proposal for a Buy Australian Act.
Small Business

My Government recognises the vital contribution of the small business sector to the Australian economy. A National Small Business Action Program will be developed, designed to improve access to finance, to ease the tax burden as budgetary circumstances permit and to improve managerial skills.
Housing and Construction

In its efforts towards national recovery, my Government will give the highest priority to the revitalisation of the Australian housing industry. This priority reflects the social as well as the economic goals of my Government.

A range of policies will be implemented to increase access to housing. The Government's objectives are to increase significantly the availability of public housing and other low-cost rental accommodation, provide assistance in bridging the deposit gap, and ensure adequate funds are available for housing.
Trade

As a major world trading nation, Australia's economic strengths must depend on the strength of our export industries. Multilateral and bilateral trade policies will be pursued to ensure that markets for Australian exports are made secure and develop to their full potential.

The supporting services available to Australian companies will be improved. The Export Finance and Insurance Corporation, the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation and the Trade Commissioner Service will be reviewed with a view to improving their effectiveness.
Primary Industry

The rural sector remains of fundamental importance to Australia's export earning capacity. My Government is committed to progressive long term policies designed to ensure a strong rural sector. Although recent widespread rainfall has reduced the extent of the drought over Eastern Australia, a large area is still classed as rain-deficient.
Measures to ensure equitable treatment for farmers during the drought and beyond will continue to be given high priority.
The role and function of statutory marketing authorities will be reviewed.
A national soil conservation program will be introduced.
Legislation of significance to the rural sector will include reform of the administration of the meat and livestock industry, and a new wheat marketing plan to apply from the 1984-85 season.
Resources

In consultation with the States, my Government will review the Study on the Perspective on Water Resources to the Year 2000 as a basis for determining national water resource priorities. The Government will consider the establishment of an institute of freshwater studies to investigate water quality , and, as a matter of priority, advise on the equitable and effective management of the River Murray system.
The Government will promote the pursuit of comprehensive knowledge of the oceans in the 200-mile exclusive economic zone around Australia.
The Government is reviewing the operation of the Commonwealth and State legislation covering off-shore petroleum and mining activities.

The Australian coal mining industry is experiencing severe problems, largely created by depressed international prices. An Australian Coal Consultative Council has been established so that governments, industry and unions can co- operate in the task of maintaining the strength and stability of the industry.
The task of national reconstruction calls for a major national effort to improve the efficiency of the basic economic infrastructure.
Transport
An Inter-State Commission will be established to develop a balanced national transport framework.
There will be a national inquiry into the road freight industry to undertake, in co-operation with the States, a wide-ranging examination of the problems currently facing the industry.
The Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program will continue, in addition to other road programs.

Measures will be taken in co-operation with the States, within current budgetary restrictions, to improve the efficiency of national rail services and to upgrade designated railway routes of national importance, including port and rail facilities for exports.

The Government is considering steps which might be taken to place the Australian Shipping Commission and the Australian National Railways Commission on an improved commercial basis. Legislation will be introduced to provide financial incentives for the expansion of Australia's shipping industry.
Australia intends to become a party to the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships 1973 and the Protocol of 1978 which amends that Convention.
My Government recognises the importance of the aviation industry to the Australian economy and the Australian quality of life.

The national airline, TAA, will remain in full public ownership. Consideration will be given to the capital needs of both TAA and Qantas and steps will be taken to place them on an improved commercial basis.
My Government is considering the establishment of an airports authority to plan , develop and operate the major airports.
The Government will promote participation by the community, the users and industry employees in decision-making on aviation issues, especially the provision of airports.
My Government is mindful of the significance of the general aviation sector and will ensure that it is fully consulted on its regulation and levels of costs attributed to it.
Communications
You will be asked to consider legislation to establish the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to give the ABC a clear charter, a modern structure and effective, businesslike management.
The Broadcasting and Television Act will be amended to remove the ban on political news and comment applying to radio and television stations in the three days before Federal and State elections.
To stimulate innovation and expansion in the area of radio- communications and to control interference in the radio frequency spectrum, a radiocommunications bill will be introduced this Session.
My Government's efforts in the communications area will form a significant Australian contribution to the World Communications Year of 1983.
Science and Technology

My Government will use the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme to encourage the development of new high technology industries in Australia, with particular emphasis on biotechnology.
Australia will increase the level of its scientific work in Antarctica and provide more effective transport links including landing strips.
My Government will work to decrease Australia's technological dependence and raise levels of community understanding in science and technology.

Recognising the impact of technological change on educational and employment opportunities, the Government will allocate funds to provide secondary schools, including needy non-government schools, with computers. It is intended eventually to extend this program to primary schools.
Education and Youth Affairs
In recognition of its pre-eminent concern to meet the needs of our young people , the new Government has established the Ministry of Education and Youth Affairs .
The Government is determined to restore the confidence of the community in the nation's public education system while at the same time assisting in the operation of non-government schools.
My Government is firmly committed to the principle of genuine equality of educational opportunity and the elimination of disadvantage and discrimination.
A major effort will be applied to increasing the numbers of young people who complete their secondary education and to increasing the numbers who continue into tertiary education.
The education assistance schemes will be progressively improved as budgetary circumstances permit.
In consultation with the States, my Government seeks to expand training opportunities in educational institutions for young people and adults affected by technological change and unemployment.

In response to social and economic changes affecting work patterns and the availability of work, the Government will encourage developments designed to equip young people to engage in innovative enterprises.

While current unemployment falls with particular severity on young people, the problem of the demand for jobs concerns the whole community. At the Economic Summit Conference, my advisers undertook to examine co-operatively the possibility of providing fulfilment in life for some of our people alongside the conventional production system.
Social Security
The deep economic recession has exposed serious inequalities in Australian society.
My Government is deeply committed to the elimination of poverty and gross inequality and a wide range of policies will be progressively implemented towards that goal.
My advisers note with deep satisfaction the centrality given to the need for reform in the welfare area during the recent Economic Summit Conference and in its communique.
The highest priority has been given to assistance to the unemployed and legislation will be introduced immediately to increase the single adult rate of unemployment benefit.
Further initiatives will be taken in the areas of child care, lone parents, the aged, widowed, invalid and the disabled and the sick.
Health

My Government will proceed to fulfil its undertaking with regard to the proposed Medicare arrangements, to ensure that the costs of health care in Australia are fairly shared and that proper health care is available to all.

My Government will end the existing fragmentation of policies and funding for the aged through the creation of an Office of Aged Care. The Government proposes to modify the present over-emphasis on nursing home care for the aged and improve the availability of hostels and community care services.
Veterans' Affairs
A Royal Commission will be established to inquire into the effects of herbicides and pesticides on veterans of the Vietnam war.
The Government will proceed to modernise the Repatriation Act, including the Appeals system, to remove existing anomalies.
Sport, Recreation and Tourism
The great cost to this nation of avoidable ill-health was a significant factor in my Government's decision to establish a Ministry of Sport, Recreation and Tourism.
My Government will move to increase the availability of sport, physical fitness and recreation facilities throughout the Australian community.

My Government fully recognises the importance of tourism to the Australian economy. The role of the Australian Tourist Commission will be strengthened. Emphasis will be given to the promotion overseas of Australia's tourist potential and to measures to encourage domestic tourism.
The Arts

My Government places great importance on the role of the arts in the development of the national character and identity. Support for the arts will be aimed at widening the access to, and participation in, the arts by all sections of the community.
The development of the Australian film industry will be encouraged by amendment to the legislation providing taxation incentives for the production of Australian films.
The Environment
My new Government has been elected with a very clear mandate from the people of Australia to protect the Australian environment.

My Government is convinced that it would be a gross dereliction of its Constitutional responsibility were it to fail to carry out the clear wishes of the overwhelming majority of the Australian people.
The national Government is obliged to protect Australia's natural and cultural heritage, including the South-West Tasmanian wilderness.
Legislation will be introduced this day to protect areas identified as being of World Heritage status.
My Government is also committed to investigating possibilities for alternative hydro electricity schemes and employment-generating activities in Tasmania.
The Government will move to include the whole of the Great Barrier Reef in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.
My Government will improve the measures to protect Australia's fauna and flora, including the introduction of a national kangaroo monitoring group.
Aboriginals
My Government is deeply committed to the discharge of its Constitutional responsibility towards the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people.

My Government seeks a national approach to the rights, status and living standards of these most disadvantaged of our fellow Australians. Discussion will be undertaken with the States and Territories to establish a consistent national approach to Aboriginal land rights. At all stages, there will be full consultation with the Aboriginal people.
Parliamentary, Legal and Constitutional Reform

A wide range of proposals and legislation designed to enhance the quality of government in Australia and to strengthen the foundations of Parliamentary democracy will be submitted for your consideration.
My advisers deeply believe that public confidence in the effectiveness and integrity of our parliamentary institution must be strengthened.
Legislation will be introduced to ensure that the principle of one vote-one value is clearly established.
My Government will introduce public funding of election campaigns and measures to reduce the incidence of informal voting through simpler voting procedures.
The Parliamentary Committee system of the national Parliament will be strengthened to give Members of Parliament a more effective role and participation in the great affairs of this nation.
My Government proposes to amend the Parliamentary contributory superannuation scheme in line with the general agreement that restraint should be shared by all sections of the community.

My Government proposes to place before you a Bill for a referendum on Fixed Term Parliaments, involving the setting of a fixed date for general elections to provide greater stability in the Australian political system.
My Government will be supporting a systematic review of the Constitution with a view to developing a consensus on modernisation of the Australian Constitution by the Bicentennial year of 1988.
It is also proposed to develop, in consultation with the States and the Judiciary, a Constitutional amendment to provide for a single national courts system.
My Government is committed to bringing self-government to the Australian Capital Territory. As a first step, a broad range of local government powers will be transferred to the House of Assembly.
For the first time in the nation's history, a Commonwealth Department has been created with specific responsibility for local government.

The Freedom of Information Act 1982 will be amended to broaden and make more effective its operation. Complementary legislation will be introduced to provide a legislative basis for the management of all government records and archives.
The Family Law Amendment Bill will be re-introduced, with further amendments to give effect to recommendations of the Parliamentary Joint Select Committee.
My advisers are considering the establishment of a National Maintenance Collection and Enforcement Agency and ways of improving the delivery of legal aid services.

Bills will be introduced so as to abolish the residual and anachronistic Constitutional links with the United Kingdom, but not affecting the Constitutional position of Her Majesty the Queen of Australia.
The Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act of 1979 will be amended to define more precisely the Organization's jurisdiction and to ensure its private and public accountability.

A comprehensive review of company and securities law will be undertaken by the Company and Securities Law Review Committee; and the Trade Practices Act and the operations of the Trade Practices Commission will also be reviewed.
The proposal for a National Crimes Commission will be reviewed. My advisers are considering a revised Criminal Investigation Bill.
A Directorate of Public Prosecutions for the Commonwealth is under active consideration.

My advisers are considering a number of initiatives relating to human rights, especially in regard to the elimination of all forms of discrimination on the grounds of sex or race and the enactment of an Australian Bill of Rights.
Status of Women
Legislation will be introduced dealing with discrimination on the basis of sex or marital status.
My Government will ensure that women are appointed to key government advisory bodies.

Mechanisms will be established for consultation with women throughout the community. Australia will ratify the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women.

Through the Office of the Status of Women, within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, my Government is determined to ensure that the concerns of women are made an integral part of all government policies and programs.
In co-operation with the States and community groups, my Government will co- ordinate the provision of emergency services for women and children in need of crisis care.

My advisers place great significance on the fact that the agreed Communique of the Economic Summit Conference stresses that the basic rights of women should be recognised and protected and that the move towards greater equality and independence for women should be encouraged.
Migrants
Migrants have contributed significantly to Australia's national interest.
My Government will give special consideration to Family Reunion Programs and will continue to recognise United Nations and humanitarian obligations in respect to refugees.
The services available to migrants to facilitate their settlement into the Australian community will be co-ordinated and upgraded.
The Citizenship Act will be amended to remove anomalies and discrimination. The Migration Act will be amended to remove discrimination between Commonwealth and non-Commonwealth citizens.
Australian Public Service
My Government recognises that an effective public service is an integral part of an effective democracy.

My Government will strengthen the effectiveness and efficiency of the Australian Public Service. The Public Service Board will be expected to promote efficiency, with particular attention to the impact of new technology in Government departments.
The Board will be asked to establish a special unit to develop more participatory forms of management within the service.

My advisers are currently considering the creation of a special division of senior officers appointed by the Governor-General in Council with a view to creating a more open and responsive service, and to making more effective use of talents and skills outside the service.
The present staff ceiling system is being reviewed to remove the justifiable dissatisfaction about its operation.
The British subject requirement for permanent employment in the Public Service will be replaced with an Australian citizenship requirement.
Repressive legislation which unfairly restricts the freedom of Commonwealth employees to exercise their basic industrial rights will be repealed.
The Ombudsman Act is being reviewed to develop the Ombudsman role. An Office of Defence Force Ombudsman is to be created and vested in the Commonwealth Ombudsman.
A Defence Force pay-fixing tribunal will be established.
Defence and Foreign Affairs
The defence and security of Australia and the integrity of her territory is the fundamental obligation of the Government of Australia.

My Government will continue programs now underway and review the content and priorities of defence forward planning. Despite the economic constraints, my Government will make a significant investment of the nation's resources in defence preparedness, maximising defence procurement in Australia.
My Government will seek to develop close working relations with our neighbours in South-East Asia and the South Pacific to contribute to the stability and security of our region.
My advisers seek to ensure that relations with the member nations of ASEAN are placed on the firmest possible footing through closer and more frequent consultations at the highest level.
The Fourteenth South Pacific Forum bringing together Heads of Government of the region will be held in Australia later this year.
My Government will maintain its close and wide-ranging relations with Japan, and continue to broaden relations with the People's Republic of China.
Our close relationship with the United States, built up over many decades within the framework of the ANZUS Treaty, will be maintained.

My advisers propose to have discussions with the United States administration at the highest level to ensure that the interpretation and application of the provisions of the ANZUS Treaty are mutually consistent.
Normal relations are being re-established with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
Particular emphasis will be given to support for bilateral and multilateral arms control arrangements.

In general, the conduct of Australia's international relations is presently characterised by a high degree of consensus and continuity. In all aspects of our international relationship my Government will be using Australia's influence to try to ensure as far as possible that the conditions for an internationally peaceful world are strengthened.
Senators and Members of the House of Representatives:
My new Government has pledged itself to the pursuit of national reconciliation, national recovery and national reconstruction.

This one day sitting, of which all members of this new Parliament have been aware for some weeks, was not our idea. It was not our idea that the Parliament should sit for one day in the first four months of this year. The responsibility of our finding ourselves in this predicament belongs to the former member for Wannon, the former Prime Minister of this country, and anybody who collaborated with him in making the decision to call the election 10 months early. The responsibility does not lie with this side of the House. We are not unhappy about being here, but it ought to be understood that $21m has been wasted by calling the election prematurely. This means that the procedures of the House as they ought to have been conducted commencing in February of this year have not been attended to. The delay being proposed by the Opposition in regard to these Bills would mean a delay of bushfire and drought payments. The bushfires and the drought, which these Bills encompass, are some of the most horrendous happenings that have occurred in Australia in a long time. It also means a delay in the increase in the benefits that would have been made to adult, single unemployed people.

As I say, it was not the responsibility of this Government that we find ourselves in this predicament. Nor is it the responsibility of this Government as it is now constituted that Australia is in the economic mess in which we find ourselves. I can assure the Opposition that there will not be any shortage of time in which this House will debate that predicament. In referring to those who were members of the previous Government-whether on the front bench or elevated to the front bench subsequently-I must say that Harry Edwards, the honourable member for Berowra, is the most unlucky bloke in the world. He is always elevated in Opposition. He never gets any of the goodies on this side of the House. I think he ought to get an undertaking from the leader this time that if he ever gets back over here he will be elected to the Ministry.

We find ourselves in the predicament of this one day sitting as a result of the irresponsible handling of the economy and the irresponsible calling of the election 10 months early, which wasted millions of dollars of taxpayers' money. This sitting could not possibly have been called earlier than today. We have given every member not only the opportunity of being advised of the sitting as early as possible but also more information about the state of the Australian economy than any 10 Liberal governments ever gave the Australian public. As the Governor-General said today, that will be par for the course for this Government . I can assure honourable members that they will get plenty of opportunity and plenty of hours to debate some of the national issues which will come before this Parliament, not just in the May sitting but throughout the Budget session. There is absolutely no need for the Opposition to cause any delay to the introduction and passage of these Bills today.

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose this procedural motion to suspend Standing Orders. The reason we oppose it has nothing to do with the merits-there are substantial merits-in the Bills that will come before us in any case. We do not oppose those Bills. We will support the Bills that are listed, but we cannot allow Standing Orders, particularly Standing Order No. 101 , to be swept aside like this. I remind the House that Standing Order 101 covers the procedure of the House, including the giving of notices, questions without notice, discussions of matters of public importance and so on, in other words, the fundamental rights of members of this Parliament. One of the last great vestiges of the grass-roots democratic system that we have here is the requirement that Ministers-the Executive-be present to answer questions without notice on the floor of this Parliament. That is being swept aside by this procedural motion.

SPEECH.PARA: To call this Parliament together for a single day, not even sitting for 10 hours, and to scuttle the basic procedures is an action which makes a total mockery of the Government's conduct in this institution. Apart from the merits of the Appropriation Bills, the Loan Bill and the Social Security Amendment Bill , the Government is engaging in a parliamentary charade. We are in many ways having a Clayton's Parliament, the parliament you have when you do not have a parliament-no question time, no notices, no discussion of matters of public importance. Not since 1917 have Bills such as these been put forward in this manner. For nearly 70 years governments of all persuasions have not only backed away from crude parliamentary behaviour such as this but also positively taken the opposite course and allowed proper time for consideration of measures. These measures warrant and will get support. They warrant also earnest consideration; but, no, sweep that aside! The first words uttered were: 'We have the numbers and we will use them', or words to that effect. Crush the rights of members to probe, question and analyse Bills. Crush the rights of members on both sides to probe, question and analyse Ministers in this House. Crush the rights of members to present notices on matters of public importance.

Why is the House rising today? We are prepared to stay here. We are prepared to sit tomorrow. Why could the chamber be used for four days last week but not even for a period exceeding 24 hours when those actually elected by the people are here to represent them in their forum, the people's forum? It is not as if there is nothing to discuss. I say to the Government: Tell us about the background of the misuse of military aircraft; tell us why you called in this House a conference on the economy dominated by big unions and big business and without significant elected representatives being even invited; tell us why you allowed the conference to be unrepresentative; tell us who spoke for the unemployed; tell us who spoke for the aged; tell us who spoke for the vulnerable in the community; tell us why you cannot even indicate to us today, let alone last week , how long the wages pause will run or how long you want it to run; tell us why you backed off the tough decisions and sent them to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. And while you are about it, why do you not tell us why you cannot fix the steel industry's problems as you promised to do immediately upon being elected to government?

While you are about it, tell us why you practised hollow diplomatic protest against Vietnam's aggression yet still discussed the possibility of giving aid to that occupying state. After all, this Government directed its Ambassador to Hanoi to register the strongest protest against Vietnam's military incursions into Thailand and the senseless slaughter of civilians. If the Government were fair dinkum, it would not just protest. Anybody can do that; anybody can move the Ambassador in to protest. It would say bluntly: 'As a consequence of these actions, we will not give you aid; we will not give you assistance.' The reality is that the Government wants to have it both ways-to condemn a country and also assist that country; to have an economic conference and call it community representative, yet ensure that the community is not represented; to have a meeting of the Parliament yet not let the Parliament handle even its routine business. I said during the elections-and how correct it has been-that Labor would put the 'con' into consensus, the 'con' into reconciliation and, regrettably, the 'con' into the economy, and it has.

It does not stop with what I have touched on. There sits, behind the Minister for politics, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the man who within days of election to government told the nation he would take personal responsibility, with his wide background for negotiation, for negotiations with the Tasmanian Government over the Franklin Dam. This was to be the test, the chance for the new Government to show its credentials; a chance to show how it could negotiate and reconcile. What transpired? Two letters, a High Court writ and the use of military aircraft. Some negotiation! The Prime Minister should detail the procedures involved in the misuse of the aircraft. He should detail the reasons for his refusal to visit the site. He should give us some detail and not have moved procedural motions like this. We are entitled to ask and we are entitled to receive answers, but the Government seeks to sweep aside our right to pursue these matters in detail by seeking to suspend Standing Orders and preventing the normal routine business of the House proceeding.

Members of the Government have said they stand for consensus. Consensus government should mean government for the greatest good of the greatest number. Where is the opportunity for us to pursue that at this brief meeting of the Parliament? This Government should be focusing today on the social tragedy as well as the economic cost of unemployment. Instead, it has now risked increased union pressure-it is evident around us-for higher wages at the expense of Australian jobs. This is not government for the greatest good of the greatest number. Unjustified wage rises and rising unemployment are the last things the community wants. Yet under this Government the wage rise of one man or one woman is now in danger of becoming the job of that same man or woman.

The Australian Labor Party, with its election to government, had the chance to show that it really meant what it said in the election campaign. It had the chance to create for Australia a parliament in which the reservoir of goodwill which exists in this nation today could be tapped in a genuine manner, bringing together the diverse interests represented in this Parliament and working for the betterment of Australia and the Australian people. The Opposition was ready to work with the Government, constructively, with common purpose in as many fields as our political differences would allow. Instead, the Government intends day after day when we come back in May to take a different course, I assume. Bear in mind that we will be coming back for the Budget in August and that the Government was elected in March. So the Parliament will have sat for but one month until that time. Here we are for one day and the Government chooses to divide and indeed deride the institution to which we at least on this side of the House are dedicated. In the words of another, there is nothing more difficult to take in hand or more perilous to conduct than the lead in the introduction of a new order of things.

The Government has, by its actions today, shown just how true that is. It will not even try to take the lead. It gathers the Parliament, strips it of its functions, dumps its procedures and dismisses it in less than a day; this with the country crying out for all of us to move beyond the obsessive issues of the past and to call forth the aspirations of all Australians. Not only does effective government require the smooth handling of government business but also democracy requires the closest scrutiny of that business by the people's elected representatives. That is why our Standing Orders provide for Question Time and provide for proper and effective debate to ensure effective scrutiny of that government business. Yet, the Government sweeps aside our rights as if attendance here is a mere adjunct to its ambitions. That is why we will not allow this course and why we have protested as we have and as we will.

APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1982-83

Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1982-83, together with Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1982-83, comprises certain urgent appropriation measures which cannot reasonably await the passage of the Additional Estimates in the main autumn sittings. Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1982-83 is a Bill for the ordinary annual services of the Government. The need for these measures arises out of abnormally large calls on the contingency provisions-the advances to the Minister for Finance-contained in the Appropriation Acts (Nos 1 and 2) 1982-83. The Government was advised immediately on coming to office that, on the basis of information then available , urgent expenditures not foreseen at the time of the Budget could be expected to exceed the amounts available in the advances by early May, with further substantial calls on them by the end of that month; this initial expectation has been reinforced by subsequent monitoring of the situation.

There is an urgent need to seek interim appropriation measures before the passage of the Additional Estimates in the usual way in the main autumn sittings . The additional amounts sought in these interim appropriations total $407.3m- $ 211.3m in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and $196m in Appropriation Bill (No. 4).

The principal factors underlying the abnormally large calls on the contingency provisions include post-Budget initiatives of the previous Government arising, inter alia, out of a fall in economic activity, the costs of the general election, drought and other natural disaster relief and associated costs, and higher than expected cost increases in some areas such as electricity charges. While the additional appropriations sought in this Bill, and those that will be the subject of the normal Additional Estimates in the main sittings, have been partly offset by savings in appropriations made by the Appropriation Acts (Nos 1 and 2) 1982-83, they nevertheless reflect the more general pressures that have led to the substantial blow-out in the Budget deficit. A statement of such savings will, as is usual, be provided to the House at the time of the Additional Estimates.

In seeking these interim appropriations, the Government has had uppermost in its mind two important matters of parliamentary principle. They are: Firstly, the right of the Parliament to appropriate public moneys for specific purposes subject to accepted principles relating to the contingency provisions under the advances to the Minister for Finance; and secondly, the need to minimise the effects of not being able to avail ourselves of the normal processes for the scrutiny of estimates of expenditure. The provisions sought in the Bills have therefore been carefully chosen with a view to minimising the amount of supplementation for the contingency advances while avoiding matters which the Parliament might reasonably expect to scrutinise more closely. The major considerations in their selection have been that, with the exception of some bushfire relief payments recently agreed between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Premiers of Victoria and South Australia-provision for which has been included in Appropriation Bill (No. 4)-they do not involve initiatives of the new Government; they are not contentious; the expenditures are urgent and would normally be appropriate for the issue of funds from the Advance to the Minister for Finance; and the amounts, or significant proportions of them, would but for the specific appropriations involve substantial demands on the advances before the end of May. No specific provisions have been included for departmental salaries notwithstanding that, as a result of post-Budget decisions of the previous Government to increase substantially staff ceilings in the Department of Social Security, the Australian Taxation Office and other areas, there could be significant calls on the Advance contained in Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1982- 83 before the passage of the Additional Estimates.

Of the additional $211.3m sought in this Bill, $50m is for supplementation of the Advance to the Minister for Finance contained in Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1982-83, reflecting estimates of urgent funds requirements before the end of May , by which time it is hoped the Additional Estimates will have been passed, together with a margin for further urgent and unforeseen requirements. All the prospective calls on the Advance were, of course, unforeseen at the time the previous Government brought down its Budget. The earlier the passage of the Additional Estimates, the less likely will be the calls on the Advance. However, it is important that the supplementary provison is adequate to meet contingencies.

The specific appropriations include amounts for legal aid resulting from increased costs and unforeseen costs associated with the newly operating Victorian Legal Aid Commission; higher costs, especially electricity charges, associated with certain defence operations; higher rates of eligibility and increased average benefits under student assistance programs; additional places made available under the special apprentice training schemes; emergency relief for Lebanon; payments to meet higher operational losses sustained by the Australian National Railways Commission reflecting reduced cash flow as a result of the drought-affected harvest and the economic downturn; and the costs of the general election itself.
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1982-83

Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1982-83 seeks appropriations totalling $196m for payments to or for the States and the Northern Territory in respect of natural diaster relief and restoration pursuant to long-standing arrangements, and for payments to the Victorian and South Australian Governments for general purpose assistance in respect of the recent tragic bushfires. As in the case of certain urgent appropriation measures I have just outlined with reference to the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1982-83, these provisions are of such urgency that they cannot reasonably await the passage of the Additional Estimates in the main autumn sittings. Payments in respect of the natural disaster relief and restoration item amounting to $34.8m have already been met from moneys available under the Advance to the Minister for Finance. However, as the required total payments substantially exceed the amount provided under the Advance, it is necessary either to seek supplementation of the Advance for this and other prospective contingencies, or to seek specific appropriations for the bushfire and other natural disaster relief payments. Clearly the more desirable course in these circumstances is to seek appropriations for the specific purposes for which they are required. I am sure that it will be agreed that the provisions warrant very wide support.
LOAN BILL 1983

This Bill seeks supplementation of the provision made in the Loan Act (No. 2) 1982 for financing 1982-83 expenditures to the extent that such expenditures as appropriated from the Consolidated Revenue Fund are likely to exceed the moneys legally available to that fund. The House will be aware that expenditures from the CRF in any financial year may not exceed the moneys available to it. While there is standing authority to meet certain expenditures from the Loan Fund, such as payments to or for the States for capital assistance and roads grants, successive governments have found it necessary to introduce legislation to authorise borrowings for and expenditure in respect of services for which the Parliament has appropriated moneys from the CRF. The simplest and traditional means of seeking such authority has been a loan Bill for the purpose of funding defence expenditure from Loan Fund. Such legislation does not therefore authorise expenditure in excess of those for which valid appropriations of the CRF already exist-other than expenditures in respect of the costs of the relevant borrowings; it merely provides for the funding of such expenditures from Loan Fund to the extent that moneys of the CRF are insufficient.

The Parliament passed the Loan Act (No. 2) 1982 in the Budget sittings authorising the charging of defence expenditure up to $1,500m to the Loan Fund. In introducing the legislation into the House in October last year, the former Treasurer indicated that prospective expenditures looked like exceeding the Budget by some $750m. Since that time revised estimates of receipts and outlays have indicated a prospective deficit of the order of $4 1/2 billion, nearly $3 billion in excess of the budgeted deficit of $1.7 billion and substantially higher than that in prospect in October 1982. These revisions to the Estimates reflect of course on the Government's funding arrangements and it has become necessary to seek supplementation of the authority under the Loan Act (No. 2) 1982 to charge CRF expenditures to Loan Fund.

To achieve this purpose the Bill proposes, firstly, that the authority under the Loan Act (No. 2) 1982 to charge defence expenditures to Loan Fund be increased by $1200m; and, secondly, as defence expenditures may not be charged to Loan Fund retrospectively, that authority be provided to reimburse the CRF from Loan Fund in respect of other expenditures up to the limit of the Commonwealth's Loan Council borrowing program. I consider these additional authorisations provide an adequate margin to enable the Government to meet the prospective deficit in the CRF. However, the margin sought is contingent on the urgent passage of the Bill since, as I have previously stated, defence expenditure cannot be charged retrospectively to Loan Fund. I would emphasise that this measure does not of itself authorise additional expenditures over and above what the Parliament has already approved; it merely provides the mechanisms for the financing of such expenditures.

As well I want to take the opportunity to indicate that, having regard to the need to pass these measures urgently in this one day sitting and notwithstanding that the items involved are of a straightforward nature, I support the reference of the Acts, when passed, to the Estimates committees in the other place for examination when the Additional Estimates are being considered in the autumn sitting. This will prove an opportunity, albeit retrospectively, for the normal Estimates scrutiny process to proceed. I have circulated to honourable members explanatory notes giving details of the proposed additional appropriations. I seek leave to table those documents.

Soon after the fire disaster in South Australia, we had a flood disaster, in which millions of dollars were lost and property damage was incurred, and the same conditions as pertain to fire do not, of course, apply to flood. So there seems to be a need for the Government to codify and clarify the type of assistance which is automatically provided under the existing system in relation to State governments.

I turn to the question of the Summit. My colleague the honourable member for Ryan dealt with the matter at some length and made some pertinent comments about it. It was marked by a number of factors. One of them was mentioned by the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) when he said: 'The Government will make decisions'. It would seem that the last thing the Government wanted to do was to make decisions on its own initiative when it constructed the Summit in this place the other week. In any event, we all know that there was great eagerness by most of the people who attended that Summit, if not all of them, to achieve something. They did not come here to propagandise. The debates here to which one could listen or which one could read about proved that point. However, the public's vision of the Summit, that it was a consensus and that from it will come great economic progress, or at least that there will come programs which will assist the community in its many present problems, is quickly eroding.
It is interesting to compare parts of the printed communique. One of them, paragraph 20, appears on the front page of the Australian today. It states:

It is recognised that if a centralised system is to work effectively as the only way in which wage increases are generated, a suppression of sectional claims is essential except in special or extraordinary circumstances proved before the centralised wage-fixing authority.

One therefore takes the view that there will be a great deal of constraint. All delegates who attended the Summit went away with the view that there must be a suppression of sectional interest and the forgoing, at least for a significant period, of wage rises, dividend increases and the like, which otherwise would have taken place. But one now finds that Mr Dolan of the Australian Council of Trade Unions is already making statements which substantially and significantly erode the consensus which was supposed to have been arrived at last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not true.

—I will read to the hon- ourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous ) a statement made by Mr Dolan. This is a quote from, not simply a description of, an off-the-cuff or on-the-kerb interview he gave last night. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The whole accord breaks down if the commission goes back to some discounting system or some 80 per cent arrangement . . . then that busts the accord . . .

To protect the purchasing power of wages and salaries the adoption of a system of full cost of living adjustments will be strongly supported in tripartite consultations and before industrial tribunals.

Mr Dolan, therefore, in supporting the accord with the Government which he did unstintingly last night, supports the provisions of the accord which are contrary to the results and meaning of the Summit. If that is not a significant erosion within one week, what can be called an erosion? The Summit took place. Already it is becoming meaningless, because we have a determination to support the accord at the expense of the Summit. They are not the same things. Indeed, we will not have an erosion of the Summit; we will have a collapse .

In making that statement I make no attack on Mr Dolan's character. He is simply a prisoner of his own militants, who, while the Summit was meeting, were on strike at the site of the new Parliament House in the very city in which the Summit was being held. We are supposed to have a Summit and a consensus. I hope that we can achieve a consensus. All I can say is that if the consensus breaks down, those who break it will be known. We know who they are and what they represent. The vision at the moment is not a happy one.

In closing, I state my protest at the misuse of the defence forces in spying on Government works in Tasmania. I do so because one of the Bills now before us contains a vote specifically to pay for fuel for the defence forces. I suppose that by this vote we are paying for the fuel of the plane that flew at about 300 feet over the dam works in Tasmania. So we are supporting this spying activity by voting for this Bill. I suppose we could keep it at that level. We could call it a spying activity. We could say that it is simply a result of instability in the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). We could say that he has some visions of grandeur. He plays strategy with real planes instead of buttons on a board. As has been said, he has been called Biggles. In fact, when I heard today in the Governor-General's Speech that we were to have a kangaroo monitoring system I had no doubt who would monitor the kangaroos of Australia; it would be the Attorney-General. He will make a low level and a high level pass every day over their watering holes. But I see some conflict. I see that the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) is selling all the Navy's planes and I would not be at all surprised if he receives a reprimand from the Attorney-General. The Attorney- General will not want to give up his air force as easily as that.

But on a more serious note I refer to the description that the Government gave today when it made some serious remarks about the need to defend Australia. It used those remarks in a determined and serious manner. The remarks in that speech have not been matched by the Government's action so far in the scandalous misuse of Defence personnel and equipment. I use the word 'personnel'. It is not a pleasant thing to think that Australians who may have been recruited from any part of this continent are sent spying against one of the States in this Federation. I lodge my protest at this early stage and I support my leader wholeheartedly in his spirited attack on the Government today for the cavalier way in which it introduced these Bills. TALK.START.PARA: —Unemployment is not the only problem. Poverty has increased to the point where over two million Australians are living below the poverty line. Interest rates went up dramatically under the previous Government, but promise after promise had been made that they would be controlled. All this was based on a theory which has been discredited throughout the world-the monetarist, Friedmanite policy of the honourable member for Bennelong and his supporter, the former Prime Minister. That theory was that by creating unemployment-that is what they set out to do and that is what they deliberately did-they would bring inflation under control. What did they do? They achieved one of the worst inflation rates in the world and one of the worst unemployment rates as well. That is the legacy of that Government, and the Australian people know that. The Australian people will not forgive honourable members opposite unless they abandon totally these discredited policies.

SPEECH.PARA: Has there been any indication from members of the Opposition that they have learned a lesson from the election, from the complete and utter rejection of their policies by the people of this country? He did not state that the Liberal and National parties had learned any lessons from the election and were prepared to abandon their disastrous monetarist policies and to support a new neo- Keynesian approach, an approach based on expansion of the economy and on redistribution. During the last seven years, under the previous Government, there was a redistribution from the poor and low income people to the rich and the wealthy, the people whom the Liberal Party has traditionally represented. It refused to implement taxes on the wealthy. It refused to close loopholes for many years until forced to do so by our policies.

Now honourable members opposite are not even prepared to give an unqualified commitment to the redistributive, neo-Keynesian approach adopted by the Summit. Let us make it clear that the Opposition's traditional supporters have now abandoned it. The forces of the business sector realise that it is only through growth in the economy that all sectors of the economy can prosper. That growth can be achieved only by abandoning the ridiculous monetarist approach-the screwing down of the economy for seven years-and adopting the completely different approach which this Government represents.

During that period we also had a lot of talk about the taxation system. We were promised reforms. We were promised action to plug the loopholes. Time and again this was not achieved. This Government, contrary to what the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) was saying earlier, will be concerned with plugging those loopholes and, when it is in a position to reduce taxes on the poor and on low income families, it will do so. Let me say this: The Economic Summit was an historic occasion in which all sectors of the Australian economy-

—Yes, I did as a matter of fact. I did attend and I did not see you there.

—You could have come as an observer.
