The legislation before us provides for, among other things, advances to meet the requirements of the natural disasters relief fund and the procedures and arrangements that follow from that. In a way I agree with the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), a previous speaker from this side of the House, that the advances that are required now from the legislation are a tribute to the previous Government. Faced with the two greatest natural disasters in our history-the greatest drought and the greatest bushfires-the previous Government responded generously, promptly and comprehensively to a degree beyond what any previous government has ever done. I believe that the part of this legislation relating to the advance is a tribute to the previous Government.

First of all I want to refer to the great natural disaster that took place on Ash Wednesday, the great bushfires that swept through southern Australia. The toll from those bushfires, of course, is still rising because there have been a further two deaths in the last week or 10 days. The last holocaust took place on Black Friday in 1939. However, the intensity, the extent and the severity of Ash Wednesday and the days following was even greater than the fire on Black Friday.

Certain things became obvious immediately the fires burst out in southern Victoria and the south east of South Australia. The first was the bravery of the volunteer fire fighters who fought the fires in South Australia and Victoria. This bravery led to the loss of a number of lives. Some volunteer fire fighters who gave their time voluntarily and knew the dangers paid the supreme sacrifice. On behalf of those on this side of the House I want to pay a tribute to all volunteer fire fighters. I am not just talking about the job they did on Ash Wednesday. I also have in mind the time they give every week to training and the opportunities for advancing their careers which they would perhaps miss. Fire fighters are basically regional and country people. Once again this shows the dedication of people who live outside the metropolitan areas of this country. My area was not affected at all by these fires. However, a large number of volunteers from my area and from other areas of Victoria and South Australia which were not affected by the fires gave their time and risked their lives to go down and fight alongside other volunteers.

The second thing that immediately becomes obvious is the great generosity of Australians. Other members have referred to this and I support what they have said. I think that about $20m has been donated. One can always be proud of being an Australian when one sees and is aware of the great natural generosity of Australians in times of real crisis. The third obvious point is the response of the then Prime Minister, the right honourable member for Wannon, the Rt. Hon. Malcolm Fraser. To his great credit and to the great credit of the then Government he did two things. First of all he arranged for an immediate advance of $16m to the two States ahead of the ordinary payment requirements under the natural disaster relief arrangements. Secondly, he declared a moratorium on campaigning in a critical period and this was his loss rather than the then Opposition's loss. However, the point I want to make is that the then Prime Minister declared and led a moratorium. I think that is to his credit and to the credit of all others who were in that situation at that time.

What about the period since the fires-the aftermath, the post-mortems? This is always a far more difficult matter. I think one of the things that have become obvious concerns the inability of the Government of Victoria. I am not having a crack at the present State Government. This would probably be true of any State government faced with the magnitude of this situation. But it is obvious that the State Government was not ready to implement what was necessary for relief and reconstruction afterwards. There was no structure or no arrangements which would automatically follow.

I support a previous speaker from this side of the House who indicated that there is a need, at least at the State level, for legislation to be already implemented so that everybody in that State knows that whenever the next disaster of that magnitude strikes certain things will follow and certain procedures will be adopted. For example, donations should not be paid into the consolidated revenue of the State Government. I think that is an insult to the generosity of the individuals who make the donation. Legislation for special trust funds should be already in place. There should also be ready the criteria for the distribution of those funds and for other relief so that everybody knows quite clearly in advance that if they take certain actions certain assistance will follow. For example, the ratio of assistance between people who lose private dwellings and people whose businesses as well as homes have been burnt should be considered. I believe at this stage sufficient generosity is not given to those whose livelihood, whose future income as well as their private homes are lost as a result of fire or whatever the natural disaster may be. It has come up time and time again in Victoria-it may have arisen also in South Australia-that business people have not been treated as well as those who have just had their houses burnt down. One can use the example of the need in the farming area around Warrnambool for certain basic capital expenditures on fencing to hold livestock for the future before any income can be gained. It is almost impossible for the business sector to gain any form of meaningful government welfare assistance.

There should also be a criterion for the degree of generosity between a person whose principal home is burnt and somebody whose holiday or second home is burnt . This problem has been experienced because quite a number of holiday homes were burnt out in southern Victoria on this occasion. The third criterion which is needed-this has been mentioned by previous speakers from this side-would provide an incentive for people to insure their houses. It would be wrong for a person who neglected to adopt a personal responsiblity to receive greater generosity than somebody who had taken some care in this matter.

I come now to the Federal Government and its responsibilities and problems in the aftermath of these disasters. The first point I want to put to the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) is that one of the forms of tremendous generosity that were provided during the fires was donations in kind by other farmers in areas already drought stricken. One of those forms of donation was the provision of fodder. Fodder was needed more than money to keep livestock alive in southern Victoria in the days immediately following the fires. Because of the greatest drought in our history there was already a shortage of fodder. However, those donations were not tax deductible. I appeal to the Minister to consider that situation because that was a donation far more generous than money. Money would have been useless in the circumstances. I understand there is still the problem of what happens to the advances made to people as fire relief and whether that is tax deductible. However, the main point I want to concentrate the Government' s attention on is whether it is possible to do something about donations in kind , particularly when they are given with such generosity.

Secondly, I want to draw the Government's attention to the future of water bombing as a fire fighting technique. In the 1981-82 fire season the previous Government implemented a series of research and development measures to improve our ability to fight fires, particularly of this kind, in the future. I ask for this Government's continued support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this a bit of encouragement for the Attorney-General?

—I mean the right sorts of fires, not his particular form of fire over Tasmania. Hercules aircraft have been used in this form of fire fighting. The Royal Australian Air Force has been involved, to my knowledge, in water bombing techniques. Other techniques in ground fire fighting are also being developed with this research grant. I understand that we are at the stage at which tenders could be called for water-bombing equipment so that we are better equipped to fight these sorts of fires in the future. I ask that the present Government continue to honour that commitment in order to get somewhere with these developments.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point I want to make relates to the future. First of all, the single most important point relating to Victoria is that the Country Fire Authority must be retained as a separate volunteer organisation and certain people in the Victorian Government should not proceed with their attempt to create just a paid force in Victoria and to amalgamate the two relevant organisations. The result would be disastrous, as we can see if we compare the ability of the volunteers to respond to the recent crisis with that of the other fire fighting organisation. The second thing is that the Victorian Government, or any other State government for that matter, has to look again at the level of insurance and income maintenance for the families of volunteers who paid the supreme sacrifice in those fires. Those measures have also proved to be inadequate.

The next point-it has already been made-is that there is a need for sensible conservation measures to reduce the risk of that sort of fire or holocaust occurring again. By sensible conservation I do not mean exclusion. Some people are tending to use the term in that way. In some areas of Melbourne people have now been burned out twice-in 1939 and again this year-and no lessons seem to have been learned. The necessity for precautionary strategic burning is so obvious from this situation. It should be done both in forest commission areas and in some of the hilly and treed suburbs of Melbourne. There are certain elementary preventive measures that people should take to reduce the risk to themselves and to others in the future, and the influence of those who would exclude sensible prevention measures has to be overcome. I support the point that has also been made on this side that if necessary the CFA should have some sort of power to lay down agreed criteria to see that certain prevention is undertaken in some of the more fire prone areas.

The next matter I want to talk about is the drought. We have had the worst drought in our history, the driest year on record. Once again, the drought advances by the previous Federal Government, resulting particularly from the work of Peter Nixon, have been the most generous, prompt and comprehensive ever. I refer not only to Federal-State arrangements-we successfully applied pressure to State governments to increase the range of those measures and the level of support-but also to the Federal-only arrangements through the fodder and interest rate subsidies. During debates about the drought and the need for a national drought or fodder reserve people have tended to overlook the fact that there is a national drought reserve in existence in Australia. I refer to the wheat stocks held and paid for by the wheat growers throughout this country. I think credit and congratulations are due to the wheat growers of this country for the way they paid for the maintenance of wheat stocks in this country which then became so invaluable for fodder during this drought. I want to make the point to the Government that it is tremendously important for it to continue with these drought measures and not to stop them just because there has been some rain. There are cash flow problems which in many situations, particularly for wheat growers, will not become obvious for six to nine months. Whatever the Government does, if it is genuine in its assistance for people in the aftermath of the drought, there must be a continuation of the drought measures for some months because the cash flow problems will become obvious only at a later stage.

The final point is that it would be completely foolish if the Government, in its cost cutting measures, were to interfere in any way with the taxation incentives which have been of tremendous value in encouraging farmers to improve the water and fodder conservation measures which were brought in by the previous Government to encourage self-sufficiency and self-reliance in these difficult times. I support the legislation, particularly those aspects relating to the advances for the natural disaster relief fund.

The Social Security Amendment Bill will increase the weekly rate of unemployment benefit for persons aged 18 or more who have no dependants. From 1 May 1983, the benefit will rise from $64.40 to $68.65 a week, so that those persons will be paid the additional amount of the automatic consumer price index increase which eligible pensioners and married beneficiaries will receive. Our intention to pass this measure on the first day of the Thirty-third Parliament reflects this Government's determination to give the highest emphasis to relief for the chief victims of the recession. This urgency is symbolic, but also practical because unless action is taken today the adjustment will not be possible on 1 May when all pensioners and the unemployed with dependants will receive automatic increases.

It is the view of the Government that there has been an unwarranted cut in the living standards of the single adult unemployed since 1978. Between 1973 and 1978, the single adult unemployment benefit rate was the same as the rate for single pensioners and sickness beneficiaries. In 1978, the previous Government froze this rate of benefit while continuing to index pension and sickness benefit rates. Since then, the pension has had eight automatic CPI adjustments while the single adult unemployment benefit has had only three minor ad hoc increases. The rate is now around 17 per cent below the standard rate of pension and sickness benefit and, without the May increase, would fall to some 22 per cent below the standard pension rate. It would also be less than half the rate payable to a married unemployed couple. It cannot be in dispute that the unemployed are the major victims of the economic downturn of the past few years. The demoralisation of the unemployed due to their jobless state has been compounded in the discrimination evident in the lower payments made to them by the previous Government.

During the election campaign the Government committed itself to return to the pre-1978 position by progressively increasing the single adult unemployment benefit rate to the single pension rate. This Bill represents the first step towards achieving that goal. The cost of adjusting the unemployment benefit by this initiative is estimated at $15m for the remainder of this financial year and a total of $106m in the year 1983-84. The passage of this Bill will assist an estimated average of some 400,000 single adult beneficiaries this financial year and an estimated average of 480,000 in 1983-84. These totals include special beneficiaries and sickness beneficiaries whose benefit rate is limited to the single rate of unemployment benefit.

Finally, I note that despite the heavy economic burdens this Government has inherited this Bill reflects the Government's unwavering commitment to eliminate discrimination against the victims of economic recession. I commend the Bill to the House.

This so- called accord-this deal-was and is a recipe for the continuing exclusion of 10 per cent or more of the work force from the opportunity to earn gainful reward for employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was it before? For seven years you did not care about them.

—I remind the honourable member for Hindmarsh that the good thing about the Summit meeting was the information that was made available to the Australian people about the forward options for the economy. In a spirit of consensus, I certainly support that action to that degree. The interesting thing about these options with regard to unemployment is that they are all high unemployment options. Option A, which allowed for no wage catch-up for consumer price index increases prior to the current pause but involved a wage increase of 3 per cent in the latter half of 1983 and a return to full quarterly indexation and annual productivity cases subsequently, would allow for an unemployment rate of 9.7 per cent in 1985-86. That is a total unemployment level, three years down the line, of 710,000. That was the option which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) seemed to favour.

SPEECH.PARA: Option B, which gave full catch-up and full quarterly indexation and productivity increases, would increase unemployment from 10.6 per cent in 1983- 84, to 11.7 per cent in 1984-85 and 12.2 per cent-or 880,000 people-by 1985-86. Of course, that is a pretty horrific scenario.

Option C-under which the pause would be extended to April 1984, with half yearly partial indexation following that and productivity increases from 1 April 1985-would allow for a small fall in unemployment over the three years from 9.7 per cent in 1983-84 to 8.7 per cent three years down the line but still at the very high level of 640,000 unemployed.

The difference between options A and C, if we take the apparently favoured option of the Government-option C is the slightly harder option-would be about 70,000 jobs in 1985-86. I draw attention to the comparatively small difference even there between a hard option, as some would see it, and a slightly softer option apparently favoured by the Government. But both of them, I remind the House, are looking at unemployment levels of the order of 700,000 people.

The late Sir Keith Campbell-for whom I had a very high regard-pointed out that the three scenarios were just not good enough if one was really concerned about the unemployed. He put forward the idea of an option D. Unfortunately the idea of the Summit was to do as much as it could for the unemployed without disturbing existing privileges and practices. This is quite clear from the communique that was issued, because part of it-item 5-states in part:
To arrest and reverse that decline demands the generation of high growth rates for long periods.
Item 6 states:
To ensure that such generated growth is equitably and efficiently distributed requires a community prepared to place a priority on employment and a restraint on self-interest.
However, the basic tenets to which all Australians aspire remain fundamentally unaltered.
I will repeat that, Mr Speaker, because it is very important and central to the whole communique:
. . . the basic tenets to which all Australians aspire remain fundamentally unaltered.
In other words, all these powerful interest groups represented at the Summit remained unaltered in their views about their legitimate requirements. The communique goes on in item 8 to state:
It is a legitimate expectation that income of the employed shall be increased in real terms through time in line with productivity.

In good times, and if nearly 10 per cent of the population were not unemployed, I think one would applaud that objective. But unfortunately in the communique that objective overshadows the interests of the unemployed. The end result of this communique is an acceptance of virtually no change in unemployment levels over three years, even assuming that the parties to the Summit exercised the restraint which they said they would exercise-and there is some doubt about that . Mr Ivan Hodgson, the Federal Secretary of the Transport Workers Union and a member of the Executive of the ACTU, which is a party to the accord, said this on the program PM on 19 April 1983:
I don't recall agreeing to wage restraint at the Summit.

The actions of the building unions at the very same time the Summit was under way and since cast grave doubts on the capacity of the ACTU to deliver. Mr Dolan 's actions over the last 48 hours seem to indicate that there will be a dressing up of the building union demands in a different way to make them appear more reasonable and more apparently in accordance with the Summit spirit. Of course, they will not be that. They will still be unrealistic and outrageous demands. Really if there is not any exercise of restraint coming out of the Summit this could lead, in effect, to the following of option B or worse. I suggest that there is a very real danger of option B, or worse, being followed if the Gallaghers, Hodgsons and Dolans, who are doing their best in trying to cover up these breaks in the dyke, have their way. I remind the House that Option B means an unemployment rate of 12.2 per cent or an extra 200,000 unemployed by 1985-86.

There are very many questions to be asked on behalf of the unemployed who were unrepresented at the Summit Conference. What real steps can be taken to share out whatever work is available? If there is a genuine belief in the community that people who are unemployed must be looked after and that something more drastic has to be done about it-if, as the late Sir Keith Campbell said, it is unacceptable to have scenarios which all point to unemployment of 700,000 odd in three years time-what are the questions which must be raised? What structure within the community must be questioned if something is to be done for those people? The first question one has to ask is the general one about the level of wages. The industrialists at the meeting said that even a 3 per cent wage increase later this year will definitely cost jobs. Speaker after speaker said this and yet a group of people looked at the first scenario, which provides for a 3 per cent wage increase, and allowed it to go virtually unquestioned in the minds of Government Ministers. How does one agree to further wage increases if one knows that they will put people out of jobs? It may be that the industrial realities will not allow one to do anything about it. At page 33 of the Summit projections document, projection C, the so-called hard option, states:

It should be noted that these assumed wage-setting arrangements would not appear to be fully consistent with the prices and incomes accord as it now stands and might well be judged unrealistic on industrial relations grounds.

In other words, even the hardest of the three projections-that in itself, I remind honourable members, will still lead to unemployment levels of 640,000 in three years time-is not acceptable to the ACTU in its accord with the Labor Party. In other words the ACTU has vetoed an option which would have some minor effect in reducing unemployment; it would be industrially unrealistic. It is not acceptable for any government of either persuasion to sit back and say that there are realities, apparently beyond our control, which prevent us from drawing attention to this continuing outrage. I believe that whichever government is in power it will have to face up to these quite fundamental questions. There is the real question of the level of wages. If the pause has to be maintained until well into next year in order to bring about a real effective cut in wages to allow people at least to hold their jobs, that should be said and we should not allow the Dolans, the Hodgsons and the Gallaghers of this world to try to bully us into thinking otherwise. We also have to be concerned about the wage rules that prevent employment.

There are very many things which are difficult to talk about within the high priesthood of the conciliation and arbitration system. The very interests that were represented in this chamber at the Summit are the ones which meet with great ceremony before this body year after year and which carve up the economy between the strongly entrenched groups to the disadvantage of the unemployed. That continues year in and year out. Unfortunately, those proceedings have a mesmeric effect on people who might otherwise ask sensible questions. For example, there are real questions about minimum wages which are set at a level which prevents the unskilled, the inexperienced or the disabled from being employed. Governments of our persuasion and also the incoming Government, in effect, recognise this to a degree by providing employment subsidies to employers in order to try to employ these unskilled, inexperienced or disabled people. But those are only ways and means of overcoming a distorted market situation which should be looked at to see whether the structure of minimum wages in Australia is one which automatically forces those people out of jobs. The next area is the working rules of various kinds, such as penalty rates which affect small business and the growth areas of the economy, such as the knowledge and leisure industries, where people might want to employ others to service the needs of the vast majority of the population who are looking for things in their leisure hours.

Also, there is the possibility of sharing jobs in labour intensive industries which could be brought about by changes in these penalty rates or other rules of work. Those privileges were earned over a period or secured by action before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. There is, of course, necessarily a determination on the part of those who enjoy those privileges to retain them. I think members of the general community have a slightly different view. I think that if it were put to them that these privileges were keeping people out of jobs they would realise that we ought to be having a fundamental look at the structure of employment. Another area is fixed trading hours--

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this to do with the Bill? It is a Summit speech.
—It is about unemployment; perhaps the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) wants to talk about something other than unemployment. We are committing the taxpayers'--

—I have talked about it many times. I am trying to make a serious contribution. SPEECH.PARA: I cannot understand why trading hours have to be fixed in the way they are when most of the working habits of people have changed over the last 20 or 30 years so that the single income family is much less the norm. Many two income families work during most of the times that shops are now open. When these people come out of work most of the shops are closed. That has an effect on the incapacity to share work out over longer hours. This would at least give people part time work which would be better than nothing. I think that fixed trading hours are one of the things we might examine. There are restrictions on job sharing within the Public Service and the private work force brought about by restrictive practices within awards. I think they need to be looked at.

The final matter I will mention is the so-called employment protection Acts which are being brought into the States and which have the avowed purpose, as did the British Employment Protection Act, of protecting people in employment who are likely to be retrenched and increasing the payments that are available to those people. The problem with that, of course, if one examines it logically, is that employers are required to add enormous potential burdens and take a risk employing somebody when there is always the possibility that that person might be put off. It becomes so costly in prospect to employ and then to have to put that person off that the employer does not even begin to employ the person in the first place. Employment protection Acts of this kind are in fact disemployment Acts. The Act brought in by the British Government, I think, under Prime Minister Callaghan, had disastrous effects in this regard. These are undiscussed issues.

When some of these points were raised by some of the speakers at the Summit they were pushed under the carpet because they could not be looked at under the terms of the accord which had been signed before the meeting was even held. But they must be discussed if we are to examine the structural problems in Australia which lead to these three scenarios giving us horrendous unemployment levels after three years. The provision of additional information to the Australian public by the Summit indicated that the kinds of difficulties that were faced in reducing unemployment were ones that would be faced by a government of either persuasion. There is no doubt about that. The Government committed itself to taking totally new directions. In his policy speech, the Prime Minister said:
There are tremendous issues involved in this historic election on 5 March-first and foremost, the right of all Australians to a job.
He went on to say:

For the sake of the 1 million and more Australians who face unemployment unless there is a change, those policies must be changed, and will be changed-by the Australian Labor government after 5 March.

I followed the proceedings of the National Economic Summit Conference very carefully. I have read the communique. I had previously read the accord. I do not see coming out of that Summit, the accord or the speeches of the Prime Minister, the Treasurer or the other Ministers, any fundamental reappraisal of the structures in Australian society which would lead to a genuine decrease in unemployment. I repeat, I do not see it. On behalf of the unemployed, I must draw that to the attention of this elected House and ask the elected members to look over the work of the chosen representatives who came into this chamber a week or two ago, to question, in all honesty and sincerity, these basic structures in society which are preventing people from being employed and not to accept any of the three scenarios which leave unemployment at 10 per cent or more in three years time.

I would hope that our new Prime Minister would have the modesty not to go to the International Labour Organisation in Geneva in June to lecture the world on how to tackle the problems of unemployment before he has seriously questioned these practices and structures in the Australian community, the ones we are not allowed to talk about under the accord. I would hope that he would examine those before going to such a meeting to speak on our behalf. I hope that he and the Government will learn that declarations are not actions; that intentions are not results. We will be looking for results and there is no indication that the fundamental issues are being addressed. Certainly, with this human tragedy continuing, it would be the intention of the Opposition to support a Bill such as this which provides some small relief to the victims of these structural difficulties.

First, Mr Speaker, perhaps I may take this opportunity of congratulating you on your elevation to the position of Speaker. The World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill makes provision for the protection and conservation of those places in Australia or under Australian control that are of such outstanding universal value that they are recognised as part of the cultural or natural heritage of the world. The Bill therefore shares the objective of the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill 1982 that was introduced in the Senate last year by the Australian Democrats. As I shall explain, the purpose of the Bill is not to exclude or replace other laws that are effective to protect such property . It is designed to provide protection only where property of universal value is being or is likely to be damaged or destroyed. I shall deal first with the general background to this legislation; then I shall explain the approach taken in the Bill; and, finally, I shall refer to the present prospect of damage to the South West Tasmania World Heritage area.

For many years, and particularly since the end of the Second World War, there has been growing international awareness of heritage values and a sense of concern and shared responsibility for the protection of the cultural and natural heritage. Many specific examples could be given of this sense of concern, and of Australia's own involvement in it. Australia has expressed its own commitment to heritage values, and to the need to conserve heritage in Australia, under successive governments. One of the most important international instruments in this field is the treaty known as the World Heritage Convention, which is the Schedule to the Bill and which I shall refer to here as 'the Convention'. Its full title is the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage. The Convention entered into force in 1975, and Australia was one of the first parties to it.

It is important to bear in mind that the Convention is not a solitary example of international concern and co-operation in the heritage conservation area. There are many other such examples, including instances of international co- operation directed to the saving of particular sites, such as the temples of Borobudur in Indonesia and the city of Venice. The preamble to the Convention notes that the deterioration or disappearance of any item of the cultural or natural heritage constitutes a harmful impoverishment of the heritage of all the nations of the world. It refers to the importance, for all the peoples of the world, of safeguarding cultural and natural property, notwithstanding that it may belong to a particular people. In addition to the obligations that the Convention places on individual parties, it provides a system for identifying the world's natural and cultural heritage, and a system of collective protection for items of that heritage that may be in danger. The Convention recognises that it is primarily the duty of the country where heritage property is situated to ensure its identification, protection, conservation, presentation and transmission to future generations.

The World Heritage Committee established by the Convention consists of representatives of 21 parties. It is responsible for the administration of the system of international assistance and co-operation set up by the Convention. The Convention provides for the nomination or submission by a party to the Convention of property in its territory that is suitable for inclusion in the World Heritage List. The World Heritage List is not to contain all heritage property within a country, but only heritage property that has outstanding universal value in terms of criteria established by the World Heritage Committee . SPEECH.PARA: The scheme of the Bill is as follows: The Bill applies to property satisfying two tests. It must answer the description of cultural heritage or natural heritage within the meaning of the Convention-I draw honourable members' attention to Articles 1 and 2 of the Convention-and Australia must have identified it as such, either by its nomination for the World Heritage List or by the making of regulations which so identify it. Provision has been made for the regulations to do this as Australia could have obligations under the Convention in respect of items that have not been nominated. Before the protective provisions in clauses 9, 10 or 11 apply to any 'identified property', a proclamation must be made under clauses 6, 7 or 8. Before such a proclamation can be made, the Governor-General in Council must be satisfied that the property is being, or is likely to be, damaged or destroyed. In the Bill, a reference to damage to or destruction of property includes a reference to damage to or destruction of a particular part of a feature of the property.

The Bill is drafted to draw on all heads of Commonwealth legislative powers that may appropriately be used. The way in which this has been done is briefly outlined in the explanatory memorandum. I draw particular attention to the use of the 'race' power in clauses 8 and 11 of the Bill. This is an appropriate exercise of the power since much of Australia's distinctive heritage of universal value consists of relics of Aboriginal culture. Three of the sites that Australia has already nominated to the World Heritage List are of great importance in this regard. Kakadu National Park consists mainly of Aboriginal land. The significance of Kakadu to Aborigines today is intense, and is evidenced in the offer of their land to the nation so that it could become a truly national park. This significance is also evidenced in the concern shown by traditional Aboriginal owners about the art, archaeological and sacred sites in the Park, and their instructions to the Parks Service for the protective management of their spiritual and cultural heritage. Willandra Lakes Region provides evidence of the great antiquity of Australian Aborigines, and the discoveries have established the richness of Aboriginal culture and have caused a significant reassessment of Aboriginal prehistory and its place in the history of modern man.

It has not been possible in the drafting of the Bill to specify, in clauses 9, 10 and 11, a complete list of acts that might need to be prohibited to protect properties in danger. Each of these clauses, therefore, also prohibits acts that are prescribed by regulations for the purpose in relation to the particular property to which each clause relates. At the same time, the acts prohibited by the Bill are not made offences. Should the legislation raise contentious issues needing to be considered by a court, including constitutional issues, these may more conveniently be dealt with under the procedure provided by clause 14-that is, on an application for an injunction restraining a person from doing an act made unlawful by the Bill.

I draw the attention of the House to clause 15 of the Bill which provides for the tabling in each House of Parliament of any proclamation made under clauses 6 , 7 or 8 of the Bill. A proclamation is subject to disapproval by either House of Parliament. This is a similar procedure to that applying to regulations made under an Act, but here the period for tabling has been shortened from 15 to five sitting days.

Clause 16 of the Bill makes provision for compensation in the event that the operation of the Bill, or the operation of the World Heritage (Western Tasmania Wilderness) Regulations, results in an 'acquisition of property' from any person within the meaning of section 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution. It is not unusual practice for provision to meet the requirements of section 51 (xxxi) to be included in a Bill that could result in an 'acquisition of property' in the constitutional sense. Clause 16 is unusual in that it provides a detailed procedure for the investigation of what compensation, if any, might be payable in the event of a very large claim-$5m or more. The reason for this provision is that, because there is unlikely to be a direct acquisition of property of a readily ascertainable market value, an investigatory procedure before a special commission is likely to be more appropriate than proceedings before a court. However, there is provision for recourse to a court in the event that a claimant is unsatisfied at the end of the investigatory procedure or where a claim is for less than $5m.

Mr Speaker, I now turn to the specific issue of the proposed construction of the Gordon below Franklin dam in South West Tasmania. There is no question that this project, if allowed to be completed, would destroy a significant part of the heritage value of the Western Tasmania Wilderness National Parks, a property that was nominated by Australia for inclusion in the World Heritage List and accepted for inclusion in that list.

While this Bill is not aimed solely at the protection of that particular property, it is the inability of the Commonwealth Government to prevent the substantial destruction of the property by any other means that has led to the introduction of this Bill as one of the first parliamentary acts of the Government. In doing this, the Government is fulfilling a commitment given to the people of Australia and is supported by the overwhelming majority of the Australian people. The legal situation that has arisen in relation to the dam illustrates, in a striking way, the need for this legislation and what is at stake in the whole debate over natural and cultural values.

The nomination of the Western Tasmania Wilderness National Parks was submitted by the Australian Government to the World Heritage Committee, at the request of the Government of Tasmania, in November 1981. The nomination that was prepared by Tasmania is an impressive document that draws attention to the unique features of the property. Under the heading 'Justification for Inclusion in the World Heritage List', the nomination refers to Fraser Cave-now Kutikina Cave-as one of the six archaeologically richest limestone caves sites in the Western Pacific. The unique value of this and other caves in the area has been acclaimed by eminent experts from other countries. Important sites continue to be discovered in South West Tasmania and, indeed, as I announced only two days ago, a significant new archaeological site has been discovered recently in the Franklin River Valley. The site has been named Deena Reena and is just as important as, if not more important than, the abundantly rich Kutikina Cave.

The nomination also referred to the area as comprising 'most of the last great temperate wilderness remaining in Australia and one of the last remaining in the world'. The nomination claimed that the region satisfied all four criteria required for the nomination to the World Heritage List. It claimed that it has many geological sites of local, State, national and international significance and unique, rare and superb natural features and areas of exceptional natural beauty. It asserted that 'virtually all other areas in the temperate zone have been so substantially modified by man that their pristine wilderness characteristics have been destroyed'. The nomination gave a list of rare and endangered endemic plants which occur there and stated that the area was one of great importance for the conservation of Australian fauna.

The nomination came before the World Heritage Committee last December. Representatives of the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources, IUCN, and the International Council on Monuments and Sites, ICOMOS, expressed their views that the nominated areas satisfied all relevant criteria and were suitable for inclusion in the World Heritage List. These are the two expert bodies which advise the World Heritage Committee on nominations. The ICOMOS representative made particular reference to the prehistoric cave sites which, he said, had been reported as making the area as significant as the great cave sites of southern France. He referred also to a report that an expedition to South West Tasmania in 1981 had collected some 4,000 specimens of invertebrates of which 25 per cent were new to science. The World Heritage Committee had before it reports at the proposals for dam construction in the area. Members of the Committee expressed strong concern at the probable loss of the heritage value of the nominated area if the dam were built.

I wish to make some brief comments. The motion of which honourable members have already received notice provides for a delegation of 16 members from the Commonwealth Parliament. The delegation will comprise 10 members of the House of Representatives and six members of the Senate. It is proposed that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) be the leader of the delegation and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) be the deputy leader of the delegation. It is further proposed that both the leader and the deputy leader will report to Parliament in due course. The Government and, I think, the Parliament are committed to ongoing constitutional reform in the spirit of widespread consensus which is clearly emerging in Australia. Whilst we have a basic Constitution there is a continual need for renovation. The next plenary session of the Australian Constitutional Convention is scheduled to be held in Adelaide over the four-day period from 26 to 29 April this year. It will be the fifth plenary meeting of the Convention. Since the last Convention in Perth, a number of proposals have been developed by what is called the Convention Standing Committee. These proposals include an integrated system of courts, advisory opinions jurisdiction for the High Court of Australia and a fixed term of Parliament. Based upon the ground work set by previous sessions there is confidence that at this and in future sessions we will be able to work towards a systematic review of the Constitution for 1988, the bicentennial year.

When the Convention was established in 1973 it was generally recognised that the object of participation should be to see whether consensus could be achieved . The motion I have moved is very similar to the 1978 resolution. Consistent with the spirit of consensus, it provides for representation of all parties on the basis of an equal number of Government and non-Government representatives. The Government's representatives will be the Prime Minister; the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button; the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans; the Minister for Territories and Local Government, Mr Uren; Senator Tate; the honourable member for Hunter, Mr Robert Brown; and the honourable member for Burke, Dr Theophanous. The Leader of the Opposition has informed us-I expect he will report to the House-of the names of the Opposition's representatives in the delegation. I also will be part of the delegation.

The plenary sessions of the Convention provide an opportunity for delegates from the legislatures of the Commonwealth and the States and the Northern Territory, together with representatives of the Legislative Assembly of the Australian Capital Territory and local government, to meet to exchange views. For the first time this session will be conducted in the presence of a number of officially accredited observers representing a wide range of interests. The Convention provides a unique forum for discussion of fundamental constitutional issues. I commend to the House the motion, which seeks to ratify the continued participation of this Parliament in the endeavours of the Australian Constitutional Convention.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:
That the House, at its rising, adjourn until Tuesday, 3 May, unless Mr Speaker fixes an alternative day or hour of meeting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move as an amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit the words 'Tuesday, 3 May' and substitute the words 'Friday, 22 April'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment in writing and seconded?
—Yes, Mr Speaker. I second the amendment.

—I do this because quite obviously today there has been too little opportunity for the members of this place to canvass issues which are of considerable importance. I ask all members to take particular note of the telegram to which the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman) referred, a telegram which led him to believe that in this House on this day there would be an opportunity to debate the regulation under which the Commonwealth Government seeks to challenge construction work in Tasmania. In those circumstances I believe it quite important that there be an opportunity for all the members of this place to go through the normal procedures and practices that are part of the ordinary parliamentary proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the House, the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young), advised this place that for particular reasons he wanted the legislation passed in this place today to be concluded by tonight. We accepted that. We supported that legislation. However, Mr Speaker, that does not avoid the necessity for this Parliament to sit in its due and proper form. The only way in which it can do that is for the House to resume tomorrow. If the Government has no business we would be very happy to generate a whole array of motions, of notices, of matters that we believe need consideration.

Only a few moments ago very important documents were tabled in respect of the National Economic Summit Conference and there has been no opportunity for any member on this side of the House to discuss those matters. There has been no opportunity for the elected members of the Parliament to discuss those matters. My leader, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), earlier today, in discussing the suspension of Standing Orders to allow Bills to be debated, canvassed an array of matters, all of which are important to the people of Australia and all of which should be considered by the elected members of this place.

Today we have been sworn in. The Parliament has sat for one day and we are about to adjourn for a fortnight. Mr Speaker, that is not good enough. There is every reason for this Parliament to resume tomorrow. We would be quite happy to meet whatever time schedule the Leader of the House (Mr Young) might suggest. We believe it is an appropriate way by which the elected members can exercise that function for which they were sworn in in this chamber today.

Mr Speaker, I too congratulate you on the election to your office. I only hope that you can serve in that office again tomorrow so you can deliberate properly and effectively on the matters we would love to canvass.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Sinclair's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
The House adjourned at 8.58 p.m. until Tuesday, 3 May 1983, at 2.15 p.m., in accordance with the resolution agreed to this day.
